description: Unique Greek-style parish church. Grade I listed building inspired by the ionic temple of the Erechtheum on the Acropolis. A notable feature are the Caryatids guarding the entrances to the crypt.

factsheet.heading: Dedication
paragraphs: Pancras is little known, as there are relatively few churches in Britain dedicated to him. He was a boy soldier who was martyred in 304AD for refusing to betray his Christian faith.

factsheet.heading: History
paragraphs: Following a huge increase in the local population in the early 1800s there was a need for a new large church. In 1816 William Inwood and his son Henry won an architectural competition to design the church. Henry then travelled to Greece for inspiration and returned with drawings as a starting point for their design. The foundation stone was laid in 1819 and the church was consecrated in 1822.

factsheet.heading: Exterior
paragraphs: The design was inspired by the Temple of the Erechtheum in Athens. The tower is based on the Temple of the Winds and stands 156 feet tall. At the east end are projecting wings on both sides which stand over the entrance to the crypt. They have roofs supported by caryatids, again modelled on examples in Athens.

factsheet.heading: Interior
paragraphs: From the entrance portico a lofty octagonal vestibule leads into the main body of the church. Galleries run along the whole length of the nave. The high pulpit was made from the 'Fairlop Oak' from Hainault Forest which blew down in 1820.
The apse is dominated by six ionic columns made from imitation marble. The original windows were clear glass, with the current stained glass added by the Victorians.

factsheet.heading: Crypt
paragraphs: The crypt was built as a burial vault, with 557 interments between 1822 and 1854 when it ceased to be used. It acted as an air raid shelter in both world wars. It is now used as an art gallery.
